content: The Bush tax cuts, enacted in 2001 and 2003, were set to expire at the end of 2010. This included lower rates for long-term capital gains and dividends, with a 0% tax rate for certain taxpayers. Without legislative action, capital gains tax rates would have increased to 20% and dividends would be taxed at ordinary rates. President Obama proposed retaining lower rates for middle-income taxpayers but increasing rates for higher-income individuals. The tax rates were extended through 2012 by the Tax Relief, Unemployment Insurance. The Tax Relief, Unemployment Insurance Reauthorization, and Job Creation Act of 2010 extended tax rates through 2012. The final resolution in 2013 taxed capital gains for higher-income individuals at higher rates. Revenue gain from increasing capital gains taxes is influenced by behavioral responses assumed by JCT and Treasury. Obama Administration estimated $16 billion revenue from allowing Bush tax cuts for capital gains to expire in FY2019. The Congressional Budget Office projected an increase in the effective capital gains tax rate from 13.3% in 2008 to 17.9% in 2019, resulting in a potential revenue difference of $40 billion. Tax increases could potentially lose revenue if realizations are postponed until death, escaping taxation entirely. The elasticity of capital gains realizations determines the impact of tax rate changes on revenue gain or loss. A higher elasticity value results in a smaller revenue change. If elasticity is less than one, a tax increase gains revenue; if greater than one, it loses revenue. The ratio of revenue gain projected to static gain is one minus the elasticity. For example, with an elasticity of 0.25, 75% of the static revenue gain will be realized. The three types of elasticities relevant to capital gains realizations and revenues are permanent, short-run, and transitory. Permanent elasticity measures the longer-term response to a permanent tax rate change, while short-run elasticity measures the short-term response. Transitory elasticity accounts for temporary tax changes due to varying incomes and tax planning strategies. The discussion focuses on the short-term effects of tax rate changes on capital gains realizations. Taxpayers may accelerate realizations to take advantage of lower tax rates before they increase.
